dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, the ECB's March projections are out, and it looks like, uh, they're expecting inflation to average 2.3% this year, then drop to around 1.9% by 2026.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, the E C B's March projections are out, and it looks like, uh, they're expecting inflation to average two point three percent this year, then drop to around one point nine percent by twenty twenty six.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its March projections show inflation averaging 2.3% in 2024, before falling to 2% in 2025 and 1.9% in 2026.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, Host_A, and it seems like they're, um, sticking to their guns, with markets expecting another rate hike on June 6th, pushing the deposit facility rate above 4%, maybe to 4.25%.

dialogue_turns.text: Right, and this would mark only the fifth time since the ECB's inception that they've avoided a new rate-cut cycle. It's a pretty significant move.

dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely, but you know, this article we're looking at, it really challenges that, like, conventional wisdom. It suggests the ECB might be, uh, making a mistake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely, but you know, this article we're looking at, it really challenges that, like, conventional wisdom. It suggests the E C B might be, uh, making a mistake.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: initiating a rate-cut cycle now could lead to another serious policy misstep. The ECB already erred previously, in 2021-22, when it based its monetary policy on faulty forecasts, and it now seems poised to repeat the mistake.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, totally. Because if you look at actual numbers, eurozone inflation is well below 2% right now; it's actually been decelerating to, like, an annualized 1.1% so far this year.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Currently, the annual inflation rate in the eurozone remains above 2%, and recent trends are worrisome. Looking at consumer price levels (instead of growth rates) shows that, after a slight decline in late 2023, consumer prices have accelerated in 2024, rising at an annualized pace of 3.1% so far this year

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And that's with historically high unemployment and slow wage growth, too. So, the article's saying, why are we even thinking about *raising* rates, or even just postponing cuts?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And that's with historically high unemployment and slow wage growth, too. So, the article's saying, why are we even thinking about raising rates, or even just postponing cuts?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With consumer inflation above 2% and accelerating, historically low unemployment, and rapid wage growth (negotiated wages increased by 4.7% year on year in the first quarter), initiating a rate-cut cycle now could lead to another serious policy misstep.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it argues that, um, predicting inflation beyond a year is actually "remarkably easy" now, and that certainty has only increased. Like, model-based forecasts don't just revert to historical averages.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it argues that, um, predicting inflation beyond a year is actually remarkably easy now, and that certainty has only increased. Like, model-based forecasts don't just revert to historical averages.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After all, predicting inflation beyond a one-year horizon is notoriously difficult, and this uncertainty has only increased in recent years. Model-based forecasts, by design, tend to revert to historical averages in the medium term

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then you factor in all the other stuff: geopolitical risks like the Middle East, US-China tensions, which should, uh, actually *decrease* the inflation outlook.

dialogue_turns.text: Plus, structural changes, like aging populations and globalization, which also point towards lower inflation. So, like, all signs point to cutting, right?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Structural changes also point toward higher inflation. dialogue_turns.text: And the article actually argues that "premature easing" isn't a bad thing at all. It says it could curb inflation and, like, bolster the eurozone's stability.
